title-group.article-title: You Say the Party is Dull, I Say It is Lively
title-group.subtitle: A Componential Approach to How Situations Are Perceived to Disentangle Perceiver, Situation, and Perceiver × Situation Variance

abstract.p: A componential approach to situation perceptions is presented, disentangling Perceiver (how much people differ in perceiving situations), Situation (how much situations differ in how they are perceived), and Perceiver × Situation variance (how much perceivers idiosyncratically perceive specific situations) in a Situation Perception Components Model (SPCM). For frequency, valence, and activation ratings of 55 Big Five situations, the percentage of Perceiver, Situation, and Perceiver × Situation variance and relations between perceiver effects and perceivers' Big Five were investigated (N = 126). Perceiver × Situation variance appeared high for all situation classes. Neuroticism, Openness, and Conscientiousness situation classes yielded more perceiver, and Extraversion and Agreeableness situation classes more situation variance. Situation–perceiver effects correlated strongest with the perceivers' Big Five trait they expressed. The viability of variance decomposition in situation perception and future research is discussed.

body.p: Principles of situation perception—how people perceive the situations they engage in—are important to elucidate because (a) persons and situations are interdependent (e.g., Funder, 2001, 2006, 2009; Lewin, 1936, 1946), (b) all stimuli, external (e.g., people present) and internal ones (e.g., current mood), are processed within a personality system (e.g., Mischel & Shoda, 1995), and (c) many studies have relied on people’s ratings of situations (e.g., Edwards & Templeton, 2005; Sherman, Nave, & Funder, 2010). Despite the evident importance of situation perceptions, they have only rarely been explicitly investigated (Edwards & Templeton, 2005). Research by Kenny and colleagues (Kenny, 1994; Kenny & La Voie, 1984; Kenny, West, Malloy, & Albright, 2006) has shown that perceptions are not monolithic entities: they systematically vary according to the person who perceives a stimulus, the properties of the stimulus itself, and the interactions between person and stimulus. In the current work, I outline a novel componential approach to situation perception to disentangle Perceiver (a perceiver’s tendency of seeing situations), Situation (a situation’s tendency of being seen), and Perceiver × Situation variance (a perceiver’s unique view of a specific situation). Evidence from lay ratings of situation frequency, valence, and activation is gleaned that situation components provide intriguing impulses for future research.

sec.title: The Relevance of Situation Perception
sec.p: Lewin (1946) stressed that “the person and his environment have to be considered as one constellation of interdependent factors” (pp. 239–240, italics added). People constantly engage with their surroundings, and subjective situation construals will guide behavior (Furr & Funder, 2004; Mischel & Shoda, 1995; but see Reis, 2008), which makes situation perception a fundamental issue. Although situations have been declared all important (Ross & Nisbett, 1991), research on conceptualization, taxonomization, and measurement of situations (Hogan, 2009; Reis, 2008; Saucier, Bel-Bahar, & Fernandez, 2007; Wagerman & Funder, 2009; Yang, Read, & Miller, 2006, 2009) remains “in the dark ages” (Endler, 1993, p. 258), having progressed only with “stunningly modest success” (Swann & Seyle, 2005, p. 162). Progress was, among others, hampered by the person–situation debate (Fleeson & Noftle, 2008), pitting dispositional against situational effects. Recent, process-focused accounts of person–situation transactions (e.g., Denissen & Penke, 2008a; Mischel & Shoda, 1995), however, emphasize the interdependence of person and situation (Lewin, 1936, 1946): dispositions require situations within which to manifest (Coutu, 1949), and situations could be seen as “event tests” (Baron & Misovich, 1993) that afford the expression of certain personality traits. Thus, situations may be understood as affordances or presses that modulate (elicit, permit, constrain) the expression of traits (ten Berge & de Raad, 1999, 2001, 2002).

The interdependence of person and situation is perhaps exemplified best in the field of situation perception: person and situation are necessary constituents and the units of analysis. Yet, the structures, processes, and dynamics of situation perception remain to be explored as “it is rare that the situation itself and the perception of it are the focus of study” (p. 705) although “the study of situation perceptions deserves greater pride of place than it has thus far received” (Edwards & Templeton, 2005, p. 720). Models of situation perception should be articulated and tested. I thus present a componential view on situation perception that can advance our understanding of how we perceive situations.

sec.title: A Componential Approach to Situation Perception
sec.p: A fundamental feature of any perception is that it is driven by different components, and people’s ratings or perceptions have been studied with variance decomposition (Jussim, 2005; Kenny et al., 2006). There are different approaches to decomposing the variance in ratings (e.g., Cronbach, 1955; Kenny, 1994; Judd & Park, 1993) but Kenny’s method—brought forward originally for interpersonal perception and behavior in the Social Relations Model (SRM)—has become a widely used and well-established standard (Back & Kenny, 2010). According to Kenny (1994), any rating may be broken down into variance due to perceiver/actor, target/partner, and relationship (between perceiver/actor and target/partner) if a judge rates multiple targets and a target is rated by multiple judges. 1 This approach basically describes a two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) design with two random factors, one for perceiver and one for target. If this is applied to situation perceptions when multiple people rate multiple situations (i.e., a half-block design with unidirectional perceptions), then we can distinguish the Perceiver (differences in perceivers' general tendency of viewing situations), Situation (differences in how situations are generally seen by perceivers), and Perceiver × Situation interaction (differences in perceivers' unique impression of specific situations, beyond perceivers' general habit of seeing situations and situations' general tendency of being seen).

I thus contend that any situation rating (i.e., a person rates a situation on a characteristic such as pleasantness) may be composed of (at least) these three sources of variance. This is summarized in the Situation Perception Components Model (SPCM) illustrated in Figure 1 . A situation—as a gestalt (Pervin, 1978)—may be composed of a panoply of objectively quantifiable cues, such as locations, time, persons, activities, and so on (Pervin, 1976; Saucier et al., 2007), which form the “alpha press” of a situation (Murray, 1938). These cues are then filtered by a person’s perceptional units or stable perceiver effects—general lenses through which we perceive our world (Wood, Harms, & Vazire, 2010)—to form a psychologically active situation (Fleeson, 2007), the “beta press” (Murray, 1938). This subjective situation construal as an “individuals' attempt to establish the meaning of situations in a subjectively accurate way” (Krahé, 1990, p. 12) may then trigger associated intrapersonal processes (cognition, affect, motivation, volition, intention, and regulation) and behavioral dynamics (passive, reactive, evocative, and proactive) which, in turn, can modulate the given situation. The perceiver effects should be strongly tied to enduring person factors such as traits, needs, values, appraisals, and so on (Figure 1, Path B). How situations are consensually seen or canonically interpreted (Block & Block, 1981) are captured with situation effects that depend on the specific situation cues at hand (Figure 1, Path A) and the macrocontext in a given culture (Bronfenbrenner, 1979; Figure 1, Path C). The idiosyncratic and unique perception of a situation is captured in the Perceiver × Situation effect which may depend on complex person–situation transactions (Figure 1, Paths D), such as if-then patterns (Denissen & Penke, 2008a; Mischel & Shoda, 1995), situation selection (Mischel, 1977; Snyder & Ickes, 1985; ten Berge & de Raad, 2002), or the corresponsive principle (i.e., traits lead to life experiences which, in turn, deepen these traits; Roberts, Caspi, & Moffitt, 2003).

A componential approach has so far not been applied to situation ratings and presents a novel way of studying and understanding situation perception that can spur multiple lines of future research. In the current work, I focus on the relative percentages of Perceiver, Situation, and Perceiver × Situation components in Big Five situation classes and relations among situation-related perceiver effects and personality traits (Figure 1, Path B) as a basic, first step to introduce a componential approach to situation perceptions.

sec.title: The Current Study
sec.p: Perceiver, Situation, and Perceiver × Situation components for Big Five situation classes across three crucial rating formats (frequency: How often does situation occur?; valence: How pleasant or unpleasant is the situation?; and activation: How activating or deactivating is the situation?) and associations among perceivers' Big Five and situation class perceiver effects are examined. This can shed light on different situation-variance components.

First, it was hypothesized that situation classes can be distinguished regarding their relative percentages of perceiver versus situation variance. For example, Extraversion and Agreeableness are often expressed in situations involving perceptually salient social–interpersonal cues, so their perception should lie less in the eye of the beholder and thus be more determined by their situation than perceiver variance. Factors such as Neuroticism, Openness, and Conscientiousness are often expressed in situations with less visible afforded or expressible cues, so they should be affected more by interpretive processes that should be reflected in more perceiver than situation variance. As situation perception is something fundamentally subjective, Perceiver × Situation variance is expected to be relatively high.

Second, it was hypothesized that there are individual differences in perceiving situations which should be related to personality. According to the principle of reactive person–environment transactions, perceiver effects should be linked to corresponding dispositional person characteristics (e.g., the Big Five traits). It was therefore expected that a situation class (e.g., situations associated with the expression of Extraversion) is primarily associated with the corresponding Big Five trait on side of the perceivers (e.g., Extraversion).

sec.title: Participants and procedure
sec.p: One hundred and twenty-six first-year students (80.16% women) with a mean age of 20.00 years (SD = 4.55, range: 18–46) participated in an online study and received credit points in exchange for participating. All participants were German native speakers, had no previous curricular exposure to social or personality psychology, and were unaware of the research purposes of this study.

Each of the 55 situation items was administered with a 7-point Likert-type scale (0–6) for ratings of frequency (how often a situation occurs in current everyday life: almost never–extremely often), valence (how pleasant/positive or unpleasant/negative a situation is: extremely negative–extremely positive), and activation (how activating or deactivating a situation is: extremely deactivated–extremely activated) with filler tasks in between (e.g., rating one’s personality). Participants were instructed to explicitly rate situations (and not associated traits or behaviors) and not report internal states (as reactions to situations) but rather properties of the situation itself (i.e., its frequency, pleasantness, and activation).

sec.title: Situation items
sec.p: Situation content was tailored to the Big Five domains which subsume most meaningful and consequential individual differences and imply many important human contexts and situational information (John & Srivastava, 1999; ten Berge & de Raad, 1999, 2001). Items were generated according to multiple criteria: (a) relevance for at least one Big Five domain (Denissen & Penke, 2008a; John & Srivastava, 1999; ten Berge & de Raad, 1999, 2001, 2002; van Heck, Perugini, Caprara, & Froeger, 1994), (b) occurrence in everyday life (excluding unusual, atypical, abnormal, and extreme situations), (c) similar use in previous studies (Battistich & Thompson, 1980; Edwards & Templeton, 2005; Saucier et al., 2007; ten Berge & de Raad, 1999, 2001, 2002; van Heck et al., 1994), and (d) mid level of abstraction. For each Big Five dimension, a pool of 11 situation items was used in this study to broadly represent each Big Five context (see Table 1 ).

sec.p: Frequency ratings can be seen as basic indices of situation representation in everyday life and have been employed elsewhere (e.g., Battistich & Thompson, 1980; Eckes, 1995; Forgas, 1976). Valence ratings were included because “the overall gist of the situation is captured by its affective charge or likely effect” (Yang et al., 2009, p. 1025) and “some situation qualities are tied directly to the perceiver’s emotions or feelings” (Edwards & Templeton, 2005, p. 707). Moreover, emotions or moods are often nominated by lay persons (Saucier et al., 2007) and can be seen as highly salient consequences or accompanying elements of psychological situations. Situations may thus be easily judged according to their unpleasantness/pleasantness. Activation ratings were employed to also capture a situations' activation potential as Pervin (1976) found situation dimensions of not only friendly–unfriendly (akin to valence) but also tense–calm and interesting–dull (akin to activation).

sec.title: Big Five
sec.p: The Big Five were measured with the NEO Five-Factor Inventory (NEO-FFI; Costa & McCrae, 1992; German: Borkenau & Ostendorf, 1993), a well-established self-report questionnaire for Neuroticism, Extraversion, Openness to experiences, Agreeableness, and Conscientiousness. The NEO-FFI has 60 items (12 items per dimension) to be answered on a 5-point Likert-type scale (0–5: completely inaccurate–completely accurate).

sec.title: Variance decomposition
sec.p: The total variance in a situation class is decomposed into three independent sources of variance: Perceiver (how much people differ in how they generally perceive situations), Situation (how much situations differ in how people perceive them), and Perceiver × Situation (how much people differ regarding their unique perceptions toward specific situations, controlled for perceiver and situation variance). These components were estimated by an intercept-only multilevel model with two random factors (i.e., a two-way ANOVA with random effects), one for perceiver and one for situation variance. Analyses were computed with the package lme4 (Bates & Sarkar, 2007) in the R Environment for Statistical Computing (R Development Core Team, 2010). 2

sec.title: Relations among situation–perceiver effects and perceivers' traits
sec.p: In half-block designs, the perceiver effect equals the row mean (i.e., mean rating over 11 situations within a Big Five domain) minus the grand mean (Kenny, 1994). Perceiver effects were computed for each person and then correlated with the persons' NEO-FFI Big Five scores.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics
sec.p: Means, standard deviations, and reliabilities (Cronbach’s αs) of situation classes can be found in Table 2 . Internal consistencies suggest that the 11 situations within each Big Five domain were homogeneous enough to be considered a situation class. The Big Five traits also had good reliabilities in the .72–.86 range (Neuroticism: M = 1.79, SD = .63; Extraversion: M = 2.38, SD = .57; Openness to experiences: M = 2.75, SD = .50; Agreeableness: M = 2.75, SD = .47; Conscientiousness: M = 2.67, SD = .62).

sec.title: Univariate Analyses: Variance Components in Situation Perception
sec.p: Estimates of variance due to Perceiver, Situation, and Perceiver × Situation can be found in Figure 2 . Almost all variance components turned out to be significant, which demonstrates that situation perceptions were componential. For all 55 situations merged together, variances attributed to perceivers ranged from 6% to 9%, to situations from 17% to 27%, and to Perceiver × Situation from 67% to 74% for frequency, valence, and activation ratings. Generally, variance components turned out quite similar for the three different rating formats, but there were consistent differences between situation classes (across all three rating formats). The Neuroticism situation class consistently showed larger amounts of perceiver variance, especially when activation ratings were considered (where it even exceeded Perceiver × Situation variance). The Extraversion and Agreeableness situation classes showed generally less perceiver and more situation variance, whereas the Openness and Conscientiousness situation classes more perceiver and less situation variance. All situation classes, however, displayed substantial Perceiver × Situation variance, which was particularly pronounced for activation ratings (except Neuroticism).

sec.title: Relations Among Situation–Perceiver Effects and Perceivers' Traits
sec.p: Correlations among situation–perceiver effects and perceivers' Big Five scores can be found in Table 3 . Each perceiver Big Five trait showed strong convergent correlations with its situation–perceiver effect counterpart (frequency: r range: |.44|−|.84|; valence: r range: |.33|−|.82|; activation: r range: |.21|−|.54|), which generally exceeded discriminant correlations. This was most pronounced for frequency and valence ratings.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The current study introduced the SPCM and examined for Big Five situation classes across three basic response formats (frequency, valence, activation) (a) whether situation ratings are componential, (b) how big relative proportions of variance turn out, and (c) whether situation–perceiver effects are related to perceiver’s personalities. Findings validate the SPCM and yielded that (a) situation ratings are indeed componential, (b) situation classes can be distinguished according to relative proportions of variance, and (c) perceiver effects are concordant with personality traits (e.g., Extraversion situations and Extraversion trait).

sec.title: Variance components
sec.p: Decomposing variance in situation ratings yielded that Perceiver × Situation explained a very large portion of the variance in situation perception—across frequency, valence, and activation ratings. Persons form unique impressions of a given situation—beyond their general tendency of perceiving situations and beyond the situation’s general tendency of being seen—which might hint at Person × Situation patterns (Denissen & Penke, 2008a; Fleeson & Noftle, 2008; Mischel & Shoda, 1995, 1999). However, it should be noted that error could not be separated from Perceiver × Situation here (this would have required repeated administration of measures). Looking at the other components, situations could be distinguished to the extent they show relatively more or less perceiver or situation variance, respectively, which sheds new light on the distinction between “weak” versus “strong” situations (e.g., Mischel, 1977; Snyder & Ickes, 1985). Neuroticism, Openness, and Conscientiousness situation classes tended to show more perceiver than situation variance. Ratings may thus lie here more in the eye of the beholder than in commonly attributed qualities of the situation classes. This might indicate rather “weak” situations within which personality and individual differences are more easily manifested (ten Berge & de Raad, 2001). Extraversion and Agreeableness situation classes tended to show more situation variance, which suggests that situations pertaining to social interactions carry more commonly held information. These situations could be referred to as “strong” as they might impose normative tendencies of perceiving and experiencing them. Differences between perceiver and situation variance were most pronounced in valence and activation ratings. Indeed, perceiver variance was larger than situation variance in most activation cases, which indicates that activation ratings leave more room for individual differences.

sec.title: Perceiver effect–personality relations
sec.p: The convergent correlations between situation–perceiver effects and perceivers' personalities can be explained in different ways. First, there is a link between situations “affording” a Big Five trait and the actual behavioral expression of the afforded Big Five trait (Denissen & Penke, 2008a). Specifically, traits may “translate into” perceiver effects because trait-affording situations can activate trait-specific needs and goals (Borkenau, 1990) and render situations functionally equivalent (Allport, 1937, p. 295). Second, people attribute certain qualities to situations based on their causal impact on them (Edwards & Templeton, 2005). These attributions may be influenced by perceiver effects. Third, persons tend to select situations that are congruent to their self-concepts, identity, and goals (Ickes, Snyder, & Garcia, 1997; ten Berge & de Raad, 2002), and these choices are related to person variables (Diener, Larsen, & Emmons, 1984; Snyder & Ickes, 1985). Perceiver effects likely play a role here. Fourth, common source variance cannot be ruled out as an influencing factor in cross-sectional designs.

Extraversion and Neuroticism seemed to play an important role in situation perception. Perceivers' Extraversion, a personality dimension of sociability, agency, and positive affect (e.g., Costa & McCrae, 1992; John & Srivastava, 1999), consistently manifested positive relations with all situation–perceiver effects (except for the Neuroticism situation class). People scoring highly on Extraversion perceive many kinds of situations as more frequent and enjoyable. Perceivers' Neuroticism, a personality dimension related to instability, anxiety, depression, rumination, and negative affect (e.g., Costa & McCrae, 1992; John & Srivastava, 1999), showed a trend toward negative associations with all situation classes. This could hint at maladaptive cognitions (e.g., a pessimistic–negativistic outlook) underlying situation evaluations. A perception of negativity and threat may, in turn, perpetuate the hypervigilance that is a core feature of Neuroticism (e.g., Denissen & Penke, 2008b).

sec.title: Benefits of a Componential Approach to Situation Perception and Future Directions
sec.p: Do we have to compute variance components every time we study situation perception? Certainly not. However, doing so may come with advantages. First, variance components can point toward and enhance the understanding of the “make-up” of situation ratings and thus also inform situation conceptualization. For example, “weak” versus “strong” situations can be operationalized with the proportion of perceiver–situation variance. Second, variance decomposition can guide situation item construction, for example, by focusing on items which have high correlations of the situation effect with objectively measured stimuli in the situation (Figure 1, Path A). In any case, variance decomposition can be a useful tool in developing measures of situations—which we are in dire need of (Hogan, 2009; Sherman et al., 2010; Wagerman & Funder, 2009). Third, a host of interesting phenomena can be studied with variance decomposition that would otherwise not be possible, as illustrated with the following five grand questions that open up the door to intriguing avenues of future research.

sec.title: Which and how many situation components are sensible?
sec.p: There are different traditions in variance decomposition (e.g., Cronbach, 1955; Judd & Park, 1993; Kenny, 1994), and there is not one single “right” way to decompose variance (Kenny et al., 2006). Indeed, Jussim (2005, pp. 64–65, table II) could see a rating having hypothetically over 50 components. Components depend on the theoretical focus and methodological design of the study (Jussim, 2005; Judd & Park, 1993). The current study used the Kenny approach to variance decomposition and distinguished perceiver and situation as random factors. However, perceiver, situation class, and situation feature (along with their two- and three-way interactions) could also be examined. Variance decomposition should be seen as a tool in service of theoretical and practical issues which guide whether, how much, and which components are important, meaningful, useful, and consequential.

sec.title: How big are relative proportions of variance in different ratings of situations?
sec.p: This question taps not only whether some situation classes may inherently contain more Perceiver (e.g., Neuroticism) or Situation variance (e.g., Extraversion) but also how measures of situations may function. Situation–perception decomposition may thus become psychometrically useful. There is still no psychometrically sound, useful, or acknowledged method to measure situations (for an exception, see the Riverside Situational Q-Sort: Sherman et al., 2010; Wagerman & Funder, 2009). Knowing the factors that govern situation perception helps devise better measures of subjective situations—which is an important goal of both social and personality psychology.

sec.title: How do situation components play together?
sec.p: The SRM perspective is a structural and statistical methodological framework (Back et al., 2011; Back & Kenny, 2010), but it cannot explain which, why, and how components emerge. The SPCM presented here also cannot specifically address the concrete processes and dynamics or the determinants and functions of situation perception. A good way to devise a process-focused account of situation perception would be to first formulate a Situation Weighted-Average model (SWAM) based on previous accounts of WAMs (Kenny, 1991, 1994) and then incorporate it into the SPCM, much akin to how Kenny (2004) devised his PERSON model. In a next step, lens model approaches (to address situation effect–situation cue fits; Figure 1, Path A) and two-process information processing models (to address impulsive vs. reflective judgments in perceivers) could be equipped with process-focused variance decomposition accounts of situation perception.

sec.title: Which consequences arise of (the interplay of) situation components?
sec.p: It needs to be established whether and how situation–perception components manifest and unfold in a natural context for short- and long-term time spans. Person–situation patterns, weak versus strong situations, consistency, and health are potentially interesting issues to study regarding situation components to address their real-life consequences. The way of perceiving situations—which is dependent on people’s personalities (see here)—ought to affect cross-situational consistency (cf., Furr & Funder, 2004) and mental health (cf., Sherman et al., 2010).

sec.title: Which perception phenomena can be studied with situation components?
sec.p: Kenny (1994) outlined assumed similarity, consensus, and uniqueness as three of nine basic questions for interpersonal perception. These could also be fruitfully applied to situation perception by investigating assimilations of situations in perceptions, consensus among raters in situation ratings, and unique perceptions of situations. These are likely to be important questions for future research because they can also be used to address consequences of situation perceptions (e.g., similarity: consistency; consensus: normative behavioral affordances; uniqueness: distinct behavioral affordances).

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Future in-depth research should address several issues. Although the study’s sample size and selection, scope, and number of situations was at least comparable to other studies (see Table 1 in Yang et al., 2009, pp. 1021–1024), prospective research should employ larger community samples (with better balanced female–male ratios and a broad range of age classes to account for different life contexts) and a more diverse situation pool (sampling situations not only with items aiming at hypothetical or retrospective evaluations but also situations experienced in vivo) to replicate, corroborate, and extend current findings. The current situation pool could be expanded to increase the complexity and detail of situation items. This may influence perceiver and situation effects as more ambiguity in items should be associated with more perceiver variance at the expense of situation variance (and vice versa when using detail-oriented items). Also, situations could be rated on other characteristics than prevalence and affective charge, and multiple measurements should be employed to separate error from Perceiver × Situation variance.

sec.title: Prospects
sec.p: Intriguing findings await us by including different data sources to explore the full SPCM in Figure 1. For example, direct and indirect paths—in longitudinal studies across multiple occasions—between objective environmental stimuli, subjective evaluations of these stimuli as mediators, and affective or behavioral reactions can be examined, whereas personality moderates paths. Such models should (a) vary situations, time, and behavior—three “ingredients” to consistency (Fleeson & Noftle, 2008)—with longitudinal designs (e.g., experience sampling, daily diary), (b) incorporate the full personality triad (Funder, 2001, 2006, 2009)—person (states and traits), behavior, situation—as units of measurement, and (c) account for different perspectives on the units of measurement (e.g., self-ratings on open-end and standardized measures, ratings by others in the same situation, ratings by others from videos, objective coding systems). First, such designs would allow disentangling normative versus differential tendencies and canonical versus idiosyncratic components in situation perception. Second, associations between objectively quantified situation features and situation effects can be examined to check which distal stimuli drive which proximal perceptions. Third, it can be revealed how exactly people interindividually and intraindividually differ in situation–perception patterns, definition of situations, organization of situation features, attention to different stimuli in situations, and interpretation of stimuli (Edwards & Templeton, 2005; Pervin, 1976, 1982, 1992; Saucier et al., 2007).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: I conclude this work with three appeals. First, situations need to be reinstated in personality and social psychology as they are—despite their blatant importance—grossly neglected and understudied. Second, situation perception can prove a fruitful area of future research as it harbors implications for conceptualization, taxonomization, and measurement of situations—three core problems of a unified psychology of situations that need to be addressed at the intersection of personality and social psychology. Third, situation perception can be studied with variance decomposition within the here presented SPCM that may open up the door to a plethora of novel and interesting phenomena in situation research which can further the understanding of just how we perceive our world.
